eventName: David Goggins challenge 4x4x48. 4 Miles every 4 hours for 48 hours
story:
In 2019 I lost my Dad to cancer. 

Cancer is something you never really think of until you get affected by it, but once you have been, it never leaves you. Losing someone so close to you to cancer is something that stays with you for life. 

My dad was diagnosed in 2015, but no one would know about it, he was a soldier in the fact he was so strong throughout all his treatment I’ve never met someone so strong, he never gave up along the way. Anyone who knew my dad knew he was quite the stubborn kind of guy. He never let it affect his positivity in life. Sometimes I wondered if he actually even had cancer, he was always trying to chat up the bloody nurses haha! It never seemed real until it hit in the last couple of months. That’s when you start to see what this horrible disease causes. But, even then, my dad stayed strong, and he always had a smile on his face. I hope throughout my life I can stay this strong mentally.



It’s scary and worrying that in 2021, so many people are going to be diagnosed far too late due to Covid, and more people are going to be needing the support from Macmillan, which is why it was a no brainier to choose this charity to fuel my challenge and raise money for an essential organisation.



So on the 5th March, at 8pm, I will be starting the challenge by running 4 miles, then again at 12am, and 4am and 8am on Saturday, then repeat until 4pm on Sunday. The main thing that will be driving me is my Dad’s memory and knowing he will be looking down on me, hopefully proud, but also, I’m doing it to hopefully raise funds to support people in their time of need.


Thanks for supporting my fundraising. At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Graeme sadly lost his battle with cancer on the 18th February 2021. His funeral service will take place on Monday 1st March with Aith being his final resting place with his Mam.

Graeme first moved to Shetland in 2008 with his family to set up a permanent home. His love for Shetland came from childhood holidays staying at the Pund with his family of whom there are many.

He used to come here with his Mam and Dad to spend time with family and eventually began travelling up himself to stay with family and developed a love for Shetland and a sense of belonging

Over the years he has built such lovely friendships from which lead into his participation in local Up Helly Aa festivals (even through it took a bit of persuasion) and from this he developed such a love for local events and his dad was so proud of Graeme for taking part in Shetlands much loved events.

Tulloch Development Ltd had been his only job of which he had loved along with the wonderful team he has worked with over many years. He was definitely a man of extreme passion from the joy and laughter shared with all the individuals that had the pleasure to cross his path.

Graeme was such a family man who showed such care and devotion for his wife Sandy, his son Callum and his father Steve. He will be dearly missed by his family and the many friends that were lucky enough to know him. He was full of life and fun which will live on in the memories all will hold dear. 

Macmillan is such a wonderful charity of which provided much needed care and support for Graeme and his family throughout his illness. The local Shetland Macmillan lasses went above and beyond before and after his passing to ensure the most excellent care was given to Graeme's entire family. 

Given local restrictions surrounding coronavirus there will not be a collection at his service,so please accept this invitation to donate in his name.

Thank you ❤️

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My British Heart Foundation Fundraising Page
pageSummary: I am doing the BHF March “Dechox” because BHF works tirelessly to raise money.

pageSummaryWhy: BHF works tirelessly to raise money.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.
title: Kier Group and the British Heart Foundation partnership

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. 

As many of you already know, nearly 14 years ago my Dad suffered from a heart attack and thankfully got the quick help needed to make a recovery. 

Unfortunately his brother (my uncle) wasn't so lucky and sadly lost his life to a heart attack. 

Then to make things even more upsetting for our family our Uncle Brue had two heart attacks and went into cardiac arrest but AMAZINGLY survived and we got 4 more years with him until recently. 

Without the research from British Heart Foundation I would be without a Dad and so would many many more. 

This charity will always be close to my heart and I am raising money in memory of my Uncle Brue. Please if you can, donate to this cause to help into the research preventing other families going through the heartbreak of losing someone due to heart disease along with the many other problems our hearts can encounter. 

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!
title: I am Running 100k for British Heart Foundation to help beat heartbreak

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Many charitys can no longer fundraise because of the current pandemic, therefore i wanted to help a charity that meant something to my family. I am a major chocoholic 🙈 so this will be tough, i will be stopping chocolate, sweets and fizzy juice. Along with this i will be getting in my 10000 steps every day, this may not be much to some and is something i used to do double the amount of. However this lockdown has had a big impact on my mental health and therefor all self care and excersise has gone out the window. Its time to re focus, be positvive and get back on track 💪 

Lets help stop breaking hearts together ❤

In memory of James Campbell 🖤

story:
I am raising money for a charity that helped my late father in law and he always supported them in any way he could . I love chocolate so if giving up my favourite treat for a month can help aid research into heart disease then I will do it . 

I would really appreciate any donations made , please help me make it worthwhile xx
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: David  Osborn
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. 

From March 1st for 31 days, I will be giving up everything chocolate in order to help raise money and awareness on the importance of heart disease. On both sides of my family, there are hereditary heart diseases which have unexpectedly taken both my paternal grandfathers at such young ages. I have also lost  other family members due to heart related illnesses and disease. Most recently, I lost my beautiful Auntie who simply shouldn't have been taken from us so soon, she had the kindest heart and soul and we miss her so much ❤️ As a family, you can imagine we are devastated and the heartache we have felt is indescribable. We don't want others to have to experience the heartache we have felt by losing a loved one. This is why I have decided to take this challenge on! 

I know giving up chocolate for most people wouldn't be hard. I know I'm not running or cycling hundreds of miles to fundraise but anyone who knows me, will know how much I love chocolate and lots of it too. So this, however small it may seem will be a challenge for me and hopefully I can make a difference and raise awareness on the sheer importance of life saving research and be part of a movement to beat heartbreak forever. 

Any donations however big or small will be greatly appreciated. Thank you for your support! It means so much, Bridie X

story: I am raising money for British heart foundation because 5 months ago we lost my dad, he suffered a very bad heart attack earlier in the year, he drastically changed his lifestyle for himself and his family, but sadly even after all his hard work he passed away, he was only 50 years old and was taken way too soon, we all miss him every day and still can’t believe he isn’t here anymore. Everyone who knows me knows I love my chocolate but I am willing to cut it out to help raise money for this amazing charity. Thank you to everyone who donates even a small amount will make a difference.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives including Johnnys crazy funny dad and my amazing friend Nic. Both taken too soon. (Oh and I think my grandparents but that was before my time!)

I am going to walk 300,000 steps during March which for some is normal but for me? Well let’s just say I would maybe do 30000 steps every quarter and that my fat arse has a forever home on my couch.

Not often one for fundraising but decided to do it for charity for 2 reasons, 1) it’s a good cause and 2) I will be held accountable (actually might regret doing this, come to think of it...) 

My target is 1 million pounds as that is what I feel this challenge deserves but even if you Chuck in £1 it will make me answerable to you! 

Yours 

Vic

X

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I am raising money for the BHF because years ago my grandad suffered a major heart attacks, BHF helped him back on his feet, if he were to have another heart attack now he wouldn’t survive as half of his heart works, as well  as arteries playing him up too. 

My mother in law and her mom, have the same heart defects, heart disease and a heart murmur and a leaky valve,

I just want to raise money to help people in the future as heart problems are massive on our families, 

Those of you that know me know I LOVE CHOCOLATE and this is going to be a challenge!!!!!

PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE sponsor me and donate to the British heart foundation.


Thank you! Wish me luck! X

story:
Thanks for visiting my JustGiving page!
I have (like many other people!) piled on the pounds during lockdown and, to be honest, enough is enough.
I need to shed some of the 'Covid Calories' and what better way to motivate myself than fundraising.
The British Heart Foundation is a fantastic charity which I have previously raised money for.
Whether it's a £1, a fiver, a tenner or whatever you can manage it'll be greatly recieved and go towards a fantastic cause.
Please give whatever you can and I will post my progress on Facebook after every run.
Many thanks for visiting my page....100k in March, here I come ❤

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page

Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Just Giving Page, In Honour of, Late, Sushila Devi who in Spirit will turn 70 on this 2nd Day of March 2021. 

It is with bitter sweetness, we ask you to help as to raise awareness of HCM by donating a little something in honour of our Late Mother, Sushila Devi.   Our chosen charity for this cause is ‘The British Heart Foundation’. 

Our Loving Mother,The Late, Sushila Devi was born 2March 1951 in Punjab, India.  Mum arrived in England in 1965 and married, Harbhajan Lal, in 1971. 

Mum lived a simple life and gave generously to charities and those in need.  No matter what happened in life, mum was always good to people, nobody left her home on an empty stomach or empty handed, such was mum’ love & kindness, she bestowed upon humankind.   Love & Kindness is a wonderful legacy to leave behind.

A remarkable lady, who touched many hearts, she always had time for her family & friends.   Those of you who were fortunate to meet mum, will know, our mum’ smile was enough to light up anyone’ day. 

Our mum was much loved by family & friends.  However, God, loves our mum more and called her back home on the 31st Day of August 2017, at a young age of 66. 

Our mother lost a long lived battle to a heart condition called, Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). 

What is HCM?

HCM is a condition where areas of heart muscle become thickened and stiff.  The thickening makes it harder for the heart to contract and pump blood out to the body.  HCM generally affects the left ventricle (the main pumping chamber).  The average thickness of a ventricle in an adult is 12mm but in HCM the thickness is 15mm or more.  HCM affects around 1 in 500 people in the UK.  Most people inherit
the disease from their parents.  Dilated Cardiomyopthy can affect both children & adults.  At present there is no cure for HCM.  All money raised will be donated to ‘The British Heart Foundation’ Charity. 

As a family, we have decided to partake in a challenge to complete 10,000 steps a day for the month of March.  Some of us have chosen to walk these steps whilst others have chosen to run these steps. 
Adult and children included.  We will carry out this challenge in loving memory of our Late, Mother Sushila Devi who turns 70 on the 2nd Day of March.  Happy Birthday, Mum.  We love you and miss you, everyday.  Until, we meet again... Your loving, Family x

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The British Heart Foundation has been a massive support to me since my heart attack in April 2019 and is my charity of choice to support. Donating to this  charity when I can is important to me in supporting to raise money to fund vital research related to heart and circulatory diseases and their risk factors.

I’m Undertaking Dechox for the month of March with my friend Polly. We both enjoy chocolate (especially me) so this will be a challenge for us both. To many, giving up chocolate isn’t a biggie so I’ve decided this year I’m going all out and giving up chocolate, sweets, cakes and fizzy drinks. 

Last year I raised £400 for the BHF doing Dechox. This year I’ve upped the challenge and would love to raise £500 for them.. That would just be amazing.

Seven million people in the UK live with heart and circulatory diseases, and these diseases are responsible for more than quarter of all deaths. For every £1 raised, 72p funds research in to heart and circulatory disease and risks associated with it. Im so grateful for all the information, care and support Ive  received from this charity and I’d love to raise some money and give a little back. 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we’ve faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I have signed up for the British Heart Foundation dechox challenge which means no chocolate for a whole month 🍫 (what was I 🤔 thinking ) 

Those of you who view my stories on Instagram  know how much I like to indulge in chocolate and follow new chocolate trends, so this challenge is going to be a really tough one for me. 

From the 1st of March till the 31st of March 2021, I will give up chocolate to raise money for more life saving research to keep hearts beating for longer

The impact of Covid-19 has cut the BHF research budget in half - you can help us keep future cures and treatments on track.

I have set up a justgiving page, if you would like to support my cause, please donate, any amount would be appreciated - no pressure to donate.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. So, anyone who knows me will know that I love chocolate and sweets.  What they don't see is that I have an unhealthy addiction to sugar.  I have tried to cut down many times in the past and I always caved and then over indulged sending me right back to square one.  I know that I need to look after my heart now so this time I'm going to give up chocolate, sweets, and fizzy drinks while raising money for this amazing charity.  Our hearts are so important ♥ I am giving myself a purpose, an end goal to beat my sugar addiction....this time I will win.
title: Jennah-Rae's page

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
This has always been a charity close to my heart and like other charities at the moment they are struggling to raise funds.

Anyone who knows me will know I am a massive chocaholic, if I could I would live on it, so doing without it is not going to be easy for me.

That being said it's for a good cause. I never got to meet my Grandad as he died of heart disease when my Mam was 11. 

Then In 2005 my Mam started getting breathlness and was diagnosed angina, she had 4 stents fitted and was fine until 2019 when she started getting breathless once again. This resulted in her needing a further 2 further stents. So many people like my Mam have benefited from the research carried out by the British Heart Foundation.

Any donation you could make would be greatly appreciated.

So here goes....31 days of zero chocolate

Lou x

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Those that know us know how much Martin and I love chocolate however we are determined to give it up for March to support the BHF. Please support us on our journey - no amount is too small!!

The pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF has faced in its 60 year history. Sadly it's led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, they never needed people like us and you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help them keep up the pace of progress. Our  willpower and your support will be funneled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need it most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. 

For the sake of mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends everywhere - support us now!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Welcome to Dechox 2021!

Dechox is an event that takes place every March; in which the consumption of chocolate is not allowed!

My Dechox fundraising started in 2016 when I raised £300 on my first run. 4 years have passed since my first Dechox, but it’s time to get back on it.

This year will be different. I’ve chosen to expand beyond chocolate and cut out sweets, fizzy drinks and sweet desserts too. Be gone sweet temptations!

2021’s Dechox is dedicated to my Uncle; Richard Fox, who sadly passed away in March 2018 due to an unforeseen heart attack. Despite this, his memory and spirit lives on within his family, siblings, daughters and grandchildren.

Your donations will go toward helping people with heart related problems around the UK, spreading awareness and relief to many.

Thank you.
title: Alex Fox Dechox 2021

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
For those of you who know me...I am the biggest chocoholic (choco is life) but I've decided to challenge myself to go without chocolate, as well as sweets and fizzy drinks for 1 month to raise money for BHF! 

Why Dechox?

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led BHF being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Aafia and I have decided to take this challenge on together this year!

Aafia is my 9 year old niece and she loves chocolate so this will be a great challenge for her! I’m proud she’s taking on this challenge with me. What great determination! 

Please show some support and donate generously to help us reach our target. It would be great to beat our target this year. Let’s do this! 

People who know me will understand why this charity is so important to me. I also love my chocolate so this is going to be interesting lol! I’m taking it a step further this year and opted to take on the challenge to become a Leader of the Snack Pack for 31 days! This means no chocolate...no sweets and no fizzy drinks. 

This year is different for obvious reasons so it would be great to do our bit to help. 

Money raised is spent on funding ground-breaking research and support for people with heart and circulatory diseases.

A little bit about dechox.....

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Hi everyone❤️ As many of you know, my amazing brother-in-law Adam McKnight, sadly lost his life to ischemic heart disease at the young age of 28 on the 17th of February 2016. Adam was the most wonderful dad to Blane and every day Blane amazes us with how similar he is to his dad. 

Adams 34th birthday is approaching and this year, I have decided to walk 34 miles in honour of Adam for his birthday. Everyone who knows my family know how much we love and adore Adam and everyone who knew Adam personally knows just how amazing he was. 

I’m hoping to raise as much money as possible for the British Heart Foundation. No family should have to lose a loved one before their time❤️
title: 34 miles for Adam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Adam Mcknight
Name: 34 miles for Adam

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thank you for your support with my month-long Dechox! As some of you will be aware chocolate is a big part of my life, but this year I've also decided to give up sweets as part of the challenge.  

This year marks six years since I was diagnosed with my heart condition that meant I needed a pacemaker fitted. March was the month that I found out I potentially had a heart condition and would need surgery, while that operation happened in June. So, it is fitting that Dechox is taking place in March this year. 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF have faced in their 60-year history and it's led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, they've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help the BHF keep up the pace of progress. My willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need the BHF most because, despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I'm totally addicted to sugar. It is my one true love, my achilles heel, my weak point. Not a glass of wine on a Friday night, or a virtual shopping trip. It's the gooeyyyest brownies, the super yum cookies / doughnuts, the large bar of choc that gets me the most. Especially during the past year. 

I've been doing some research on sugar. The benefits (they are minimal) and the science behind what sugar does to your body. It seems that we're all slightly addicted (or worse) because it is in everything we eat basically. I want to set the reset button and see if it can make a difference. I even got to a point around 2 years ago when my mental health was at a low, where I ate sugar such as chocolate instead of meals. As I have been exploring going booze-free when possible and not smoking when socialising, sugar has stepped up to fill those gaps. To summarise...this is a big challenge for me. 

We sadly lost our Nan recently and although she had a great and full life, she also suffered with strokes and diabetes. To be honest it kinda seems ironic doing this challenge in her memory as she was the biggest cake and biscuit lover of all! But, I think she would have liked the sentiment and I'd really like to raise some money for the charity to honour her and all she did for us during her lifetime.  We called her 'Nanny Daniel'. She was my mum's mum and she was a modest, headstrong and independent woman. From what I remember of her in the more recent years, she didn't talk too much and I'm not sure if this was related to the strokes she had. Or maybe it was due to a kind of contentment you reach later on in life. When I was young she would take me and my 567 other cousins on the train to the beach and I have no idea why she did that because there was so many of us - it must have been a nightmare haha. She would often go on train trips with our Granddad bring me back a paper bag of my favourite sweets, 'toothbrushes and teeth'. Oh the nostalgia! And again, the irony. 

As much as I love-d sweets, at the age of 29, I'd like to try something new. For my health and to celebrate the life of our beloved Nanny Daniel, I'm giving up the sweet stuff for 30 days. I'm going to be removing refined sugar from my diet as much as possible, whilst allowing myself small amounts of natural sugar from fruits. 

Things I will not be eating / drinking (and for each thing there is a £5 penalty): chocolate, sweets, cake of any form (doughnuts, cookies, biscuits), fizzy drinks, alcohol, anything that has an obvious amount of refined sugar! I will allow myself bread but will be mindful with how much I eat.

And if you've got this far - thank you for your support!

Bex 

x 

PS please always Gift Aid :) - the charity can claim back 25% of your donation from tax you have paid at no cost to you! It's a no-brainer. 


A lil bit from the British Heart Foundation:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
With family members with heart conditions, this is a charity that means a lot to me. I want to help them raise some money for the amazing research and work they do. 

Now anyone who knows me, will know I love my food especially-CHOCOLATE, SWEETs and FIZZY drinks.This will be a  massive challenge for me but I will do it for an amazing cause. 

My mum and step mum have had heart surgery’s, my dad and mother in law have had heart attacks. So help me to raise some funds to help this amazing charity do the work they do, to save family’s like my own. 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
On 6th February 2021, Mr Joseph Harrison passed away, peacefully in his sleep, aged 89 years and 10 months.

Joe was very much loved and will be sadly missed by his wife and family and his very many friends and former colleagues. 

Joe was an amazing man who had a remarkable life.  A former miner, Royal Marine and Senior Police Officer; his life was, without doubt extended thanks to major heart surgery many years ago. For this reason, Ina has asked that if anybody would like to make a donation in memory of Joe, she would like it to go to The British Heart Foundation. 

Thank you for your kindness,

The Harrison family.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
If you think 31 days doesn't sound like much..... you don't know how much we like chocolate! An emergency Freddo has been in my handbag for as long as I can remember 😂

Charities like the BHF have struggled during the pandemic and every little helps so why not get involved. 60 years ago 7 out of 10 heart attacks were fatal... today 7 out of 10 survive, one day hopefully it'll be 10 out of 10. 

We lost the most amazing Uncle due to heart related issues. I'd give up chocolate for life to bring him back! But hopefully one day the BHF will have enough funds to help their research and stop other families losing their loved ones.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I am taking on this challenge to raise money for the British heart foundation and raise awareness about heart diseases and diabetes and be a leading example to everyone.  

Help me to achieve my goal to give up chocolate, sweets fizzy drinks for 31 days. 

People who know me , know I'm a chocaholic and that this is going to be a tough one. 

Thank you all for your upcoming support!
title: Kick sugar in the butt
pageSummary: I am giving up chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks because I would like to raise money and awareness.

Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Anyone who knows me knows how much of a chocoholic I am, I don't go longer than a few hours without a sneaky little fix 😋🍫 so this is definitely going to be a 'challenge' 😅 but.. here goes. This March i am giving up chocolate for a whole month to raise money for a cause very close to my heart ❤ 

Please donate if you can, just a small amount will do.. to help British heart foundation keep up their excellent work, researching, finding cures and saving precious lives. 

It would mean the world to me and my 'world' 👨‍👩‍👧‍👧🌏

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge they’ve faced in their 60 year history and it's led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut the 2021 research budget in half. Your willpower and donations will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need the BHF most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
For all 31 days in March (with the possible exception of a slither of birthday cake on the 12th for Connors Birthday!!) I am giving up all chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks. Yes - I'm taking on the biggest challgenge - I'm a Leader of the Snack Pack!!

I've done a fair few challenges for charity including a skydive, an abseil off the Fourth Rail Bridge and climbing all 7,200 steps in BT Murrayfiled Stadium however, this is by far the scariest challenge...The BHF Dechox!! Please support me, I'm going to need it!

A statement from BHF: The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
As many of you will know, my eldest son was born with a heart defect that required life saving surgery. He will need to see a consultant for the rest of his life. Thankfully he is perfectly healthy now but I will be forever grateful to those fixed him and looked after him and us, through what is for every parent, the most heartbreaking time of their lives

For this reason, heart charities always strike a cord with me ❤ so I have decided to give up all chocolate, sweets, treats and fizzy drinks for the month of March - and raise a couple of quid for BHF in the process. Please see a word from them below:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
eventName: LCS - Guess the Name of the Guide Dog Puppy
story:
Thanks for your generosity in supporting Guide Dogs who, like many charities, have been unable to go ahead with thousands of collections planned across the UK. 

It costs £13 a day to support each life changing dog.

Every pound raised will ensure Guide Dogs can continue to help people with sight loss feel less alone, now and in the future.
title: Debra Wallace's Guide Dogs Virtual Collection
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Subtext: LCS - Guess the Name of the Guide Dog Puppy
Name: Debra Wallace's Guide Dogs Virtual Collection

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
They’ve come a very long way since those early days. Today Guide Dogs is the world's largest breeder and trainer of working dogs. And thanks to their dedicated staff and volunteers – and your vital donations – they’ve helped over 29,000 people to achieve life-changing independence.
 Guide Dogs provides a wide range of services for children and young people, including mobility and life skills, large print books and grants for specialist technology. And they're there for the whole family, providing support and advice on a range of issues, including education
Their ambition is a future where every person with sight loss has the confidence and support they need to live their lives to the full.


Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: We fundraise to enhance Great Ormond Street Hospital’s ability to transform the health and wellbeing of children and young people. Donations help to fund advanced medical equipment, child and family support services, pioneering research and rebuilding and refurbishment.
charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story: Every day brings new challenges at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). Every day, 618 children and young people from across the UK arrive. Every day, doctors and nurses battle the most complex illnesses, and the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs. And every day is a chance for you to make a difference. This extraordinary hospital has always depended on charitable support to give seriously ill children the best chance to fulfil their potential. A better future for seriously ill children STARTS HERE.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

It’s tough feeling helpless (and sometimes hopeless)when a child in your family is seriously ill. This is my bit to raise awareness, support and funds for essential research - especially for rare endocrine diseases. With your help, GOSH can fund more research that can lead to more life-saving cures. For some children, research is their only hope.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description:
We are the world’s largest charity dedicated to saving lives through research.
Our vision is to bring forward the day when all cancers are cured.

Cancer Research UK is a registered charity in England and Wales (1089464), Scotland (SC041666), the Isle of Man (1103) and Jersey (247).
charity.name: Cancer Research UK
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 1089464, Scotland SC041666
eventName: Junior Kilburns Running and Cycling for Cancer Research UK
story:
Thank you for visiting our fundraising page. This week starting on Monday 1st March we will be running 20k in five days and then cycling 20k at the weekend. We know a lot of people affected by cancer so that is why we are raising money for Cancer Research UK. 

Thank you for supporting us.

eventName: Timms Boys Run 250km for Cancer Research
story:
In an attempt to raise money and awareness for Cancer Research UK, the lads are running 250km evenly throughout the month of March - this averages out at just over 4km each day. 

Like many families we have recently been affected by this horrible disease. The ongoing battle against cancer is never easy but with our added efforts to raise money and awareness, we are collectively working towards improved treatment and research to help millions of people affected by this each year. 

With our earphones in and ice packs at the ready we are ready to smash this challenge!

charity.name: Cancer Research UK
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 1089464, Scotland SC041666
story:
Alison Wright has recently had to leave the Finance Advice Group of companies, as she is having to fight Cancer for a second time. Having recovered from cancer once already, after first being diagnosed in 2008, Ali is now focusing her mind to overcome it again.

As many professional sports people have a Testimonial Year held in their honour, we are doing the same for Ali in recognition for all the hard work and dedication she has shown to our group of companies over the last decade. 

To show our appreciation for her efforts, we will be holding a series of events during 2021 for the charity which is closest to Ali's heart Cancer Research UK. We are hoping to raise as much money as possible for this great cause, so please dig deep and give what you can.

If one of our team has sent you a link to this page for an event they're doing and asked you to donate to this great cause, then please add a personal message for them here as I'm sure they'd love to read it to help spur them on.


About Your Donation

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the Cancer Research UK. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Muriels group have been raising funds and awareness for Marie Curie from 2009, at this time of year we are normally dressed up in yellowness raising vital funds for the Great Daffodil Appeal. Unfortunately this is our 2nd year we are unable to hold our usual collections. If you can donate or virtually collect for us it will be greatly appreciated, thank you

Some of our group have pledged to walk 10,000 steps a day in March as part of the Step into Spring challenge - so go on please sponsor us :)  Look out for updates during March - cheer them on :) 

 

Marie Curie have set up Fundraising Groups across the UK to help raise money and awareness for the charity in their local area. They are a vital part of the Marie Curie family, raising a fantastic amount each year to help ensure we can keep supporting people living with a terminal illness and their loved ones. This is through our wide range of services including hospices, nursing, Information and Support services and research. If you wish to get involved with your local fundraising or volunteer in your community please visit this link.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
We're here to support people with serious illnesses in the Newcastle area to have the best quality of life possible, whatever that might mean for them.

Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 100 volunteers, who play a vital role in the running of the hospice. 

Some people stay in our 20-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish.

Our day therapy unit offers outpatient clinics and a wide range of activities and therapies, including baking, art therapy and relaxation. 

We also provide support for carers and families, including our social work team who provide emotional and practical advice. Our chaplain is here to provide spiritual care to patients and their loved ones.

Thank you for supporting us, and helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in the Newcastle area get the care and support they need.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story: Hi everyone! We are taking part in Marie Curies Step into Spring 2021 in memory of our Daddy,Brendan. Each day in March we will each be walking 10,000 steps to help raise money for this amazing charity. Our daddy was cared for at home with the help of the Marie curie nurses. We hope you can dig deep and give whatever small donation possible. Now to get our walking shoes on and in honour of daddy maybe a cap and shopping bags too! Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

eventName: 3000 SQUAT CHALLENGE - HEALTHY HAPPY STRONG SQUAD!
story:
Thanks for checking out our fundraising page!!!

All of us here in the Healthy Happy Strong Squad have decided to take part in the 3000 Squat Challenge for Marie Curie UK. We will be completing this challenge throughout the month of March, and will be doing roughly 100 squats each every single day for the whole month so that we ALL individually reach 3000! 

We want to raise as much money as possible so that we can donate to make a difference. 

Any amount donated from you will be HUGELY appreciated!

Thank you so much,

Love from Nat & the Healthy Happy Strong Squad x

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Hello 

We are a group of teaching and pupil support staff from St Angela’s Primary School. 

The Marie Curie Hospice provides incredible care and supports so many people all over the UK, now we would like to help them during this difficult time. 

To achieve this we will each individually be trying to walk 10,000 steps a day in March as part of Step into Spring. 

We will be using Step into Spring to keep us all motivated while hoping to raise money for The Marie Curie Hospice. 

Thanks 

St Angela’s Family 😊

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Our hospice is a warm and welcoming place, supporting people in Edinburgh and their loved ones with expert care, every day of the year. 

Our doctors, nurses, physiotherapists and social workers are supported by a team of volunteers, who play a vital role in the running of the hospice.

Some of the people we support stay in our in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night and stay with their loved ones if they wish to.

We also support local people with clinics, therapies and activities during the day  including one-to-one care, groups and things like reiki and massage. 

As well as people with a terminal illness, we also support carers and families with things like bereavement support groups where people can share their experiences and feelings.

Thank you for supporting us, and helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in Edinburgh get the care and support they need.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
This March, Morrisons and Marie Curie are working side by side to raise vital funds for frontline nurses to help dying people and their loved ones.

This has been a hard year for everyone. Weve faced challenging times as a nation, and we know it's the small moments that bring people together. Such moments can be made possible for dying people and their loved ones by the expert care of Marie Curie Nurses, who can bring care, comfort and clarity at the very toughest time. 

Your support means the world to people affected by terminal illness.  From picking your daffodil in-store and wearing it with pride, to taking on your own fundraising challenge you're making vital care possible.

Put simply, without the support people like you highly skilled Marie Curie Nurses couldn't continue giving vital care to people living with a terminal illness and their families.

Name: Fundraising's Step Into Spring page

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Hi everyone,

As most of you know my lovely dad was cared for in the marie curie hospice. So this is a charity very close to my heart and also close to your hearts too.

Covid has hit this charity hard and we need to help to keep the hospices open! Unfortunately daffodils will not be on sale again in local supermarkets etc... so let's raise some funds together.

Even if it's just £1, please donate because they all add up 

Thank you in advance

Lets smash it

Love Becky xx

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
I belong to the local fundraising group for Marie Curie and over the years, we have held many events to raise money for this very worthy cause.

As with all charities, Marie Curie has been unable to carry out its usual fundraising during the last year so I am hoping to help by participating in the Step Into Spring campaign.

My plan is to walk a minimum of 12,000 steps (roughly five miles) every day in March and I would be delighted to receive your donation should you wish to sponsor me.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
I’m taking part in Marie Curie’s 3000 squats in March challenge. 

Cancer affects everyone at some point in their life, whether it is someone they know or even them themselves are diagnosed. My Dad was diagnosed with Non Hodgkins Lymphoma 2 years ago and started treatment soon after. He thankfully managed to finish his treatment before the pandemic hit. However many people weren’t so lucky, due to the pandemic their treatment was delayed (unfortunately for some, delayed too long).

I would be grateful for any donations for a charity close to my heart.

Many thanks

Andrew

And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
I am trying to raise money for Marie Curie after everything they have done for my Taid. I want to show how much I appreciate everything Marie Curie did to make him feel safe and comfortable at the end of his days. And I want to thank them for lots of things.

My Taid had cancer but unfortunately the cancer spread before they could do anything about it. My Taid was a Priest and was a very good person but he died in January last year. At the end of his days he went to the Marie Curie hospice in Penarth and they were very welcoming and looked after him very well. That is why I want to raise money to thank them and help other people in the same situation. 

My Taid's favourite place was Walsingham and we would visit every year. I found out that Walsingham is 250 miles away from their home so I hope to run, walk and cross trainer that distance in March.

Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. If you have any spare pennies to sponsor me I would be very grateful for your donation.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Our Solihull Hospice has been caring for local people since 1965.

Its a warm and welcoming place where we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones, every day of the year. 

Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 200 volunteers  who play a vital role in the running of the hospice.

We have a 24-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish.

Our out-patient unit offers clinics, therapies and group sessions  and freshly cooked lunches made by our chefs. We also support carers and families, including children, with practical advice, counselling and bereavement support groups.

We need to raise £9,600 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in Solihull get the care and support they need.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Our RNLI lifeboats in Ireland protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. They rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. 
Irelands unrivalled coasts and inland waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike, with millions travelling to enjoy them, and work on them each year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Last week, an email dropped into my inbox. It was headed “They don’t cry anymore”. Starving children cannot afford to cry. Their tiny bodies can't waste energy on tears. Instead they use every last calorie to keep their organs pumping. Many however will die of starvation. As a result of the ongoing conflict in Yemen, as many as 400,000 children are acutely malnourishing and fighting for their lives. 

Those of us who have everything must help. The only thing I can do, other than donate money, is to walk. I am not a particularly active person, and I enjoy my lazy moments very much, but I am promising to walk 400,000 steps during March 2021 for the 400,000 starving children of Yemen. If you are able to, please help me in my efforts to help these children by sponsoring my walk. £33 provides life-saving food for a child for three weeks.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.
title: Anna's 400,000 Steps for 400,000 Starving Children
pageSummary: I am walking 400,000 steps in March because 400,000 children are starving in Yemen
pageSummaryWhat: I am walking 400,000 steps in March

Name: Anna's 400,000 Steps for 400,000 Starving Children

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
We know we are not alone in recognising the imbalance in vaccination supply across
the world and we would like to help.

The Covax facility made up of Gavi, CEPI, WHO and Unicef are working together to procure, refrigerate, transport and administer vaccines to poorer nations.

In the UK we are extremely lucky to know that we will all receive a Vaccination but in many of
the poorer countries of the world even frontline workers have not yet received
them.

We obviously can't choose to give our own Vaccine dose away, it would be neither practical nor sensible.
We can however give the value of our dose so that someone else can receive one.

The UK is reported to have spent:

  • ﻿£24 to £28 per dose on the Moderna jab
  • £15 per dose on the Pfizer/BuiNTech jab
  • £3 per dose on the Oxford/AstraZeneca jab

Alternatively the below values represent examples
of how your money could be used to support this cause. (Information supplied by Unicef)

  • £6 could provide 267 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers
  • £10 could provide cold chain equipment to safely store 111 doses of vaccines 
  • £20 could transport 1,335 doses of vaccines
  • £45 could provide cold chain equipment to safely store 500 doses of vaccines
  • £63 could transport 4205 doses of vaccines

Money raised will go to Unicef UK Covid 19 Campaign to support the Covax facility. Please help us try make ALL the world a safer place.

Thank You

charity.description: Malaria No More UK mobilises governments, influencers, businesses and the public to end deaths from malaria and wipe out the disease for good. Our mission is to catalyse and inspire the global partnerships, leadership and financing to make malaria no more in a generation.
charity.name: MALARIA NO MORE UK
story: Every two minutes a child under 5 dies from malaria and yet, it is preventable and treatable. Since 2000 we’ve cut world malaria deaths by 60%, but that progress is in jeopardy and we need to step up efforts. By making a donation, you’ll be helping to protect children and their families from malaria, save lives and create a world where no child suffers needlessly. That means more kids in school, more people in work, less pressure on health services. A future with less poverty and more economic growth.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

story:
I took early retirement last month and I'm now ready for a new challenge! 


I'm walking for water so others don't have to. Millions of women and children walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. Please donate whatever you can to help make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere.


Thank you 😊

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am committing to walking 4km a day for the month of March for children like Tiyamike, who is 14 years old and lives in a remote village in Malawi. She has to walk 4km a day to collect water every morning before school.

 

Right now 785 million people in the world – one in ten – don’t have clean water, decent toilets or good hygiene to protect themselves. Without these basics, overcoming poverty is just a dream.


I'm walking the same distance as Tiyamike each day to raise funds for Wateraid to help make clean water normal for everyone everywhere. 


Please sponsor me (Mary Ann Richardson).

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
WaterAid is working to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. The international not-for-profit organisation works in 28 countries to change the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people. Since 1981, WaterAid has reached 26.4 million people with clean water and 26.3 million people with decent toilets.

My aim is to walk at least 4Km everyday in march.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm walking or jogging for water so others don't have to. I'm walking or jogging for the millions of women and children who walk average distances of at least 4 km every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I am aiming to cover at least that distance every day in March to help raise funds to make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. 1 in 10 people worldwide do not have access to clean water, so have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive. Thanks for reading!

story: Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.
